awd_titl_txt: Network and Distributed System Security Symposium 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports student participation in the 2022 Network and Distributed System Security (NDSS) Symposium held in person in San Diego CA in April 2022. NDSS brings together innovative and forward-thinking members of the Internet community who research, design, develop, and deploy the technologies that define network and distributed system security. This grant enables career development and learning opportunities for US-based and/or US citizen graduate students. Attending conferences is an important component of graduate school education for our society's future computer security researchers. Students have the opportunity to discuss leading edge research with world-class computer security researchers, and establish networks, connections, and mentoring relationships that will serve them well during their research careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the attendance and participation of 22 US-based graduate student in the 2022 Network and Distributed System Security (NDSS) Symposium held in San Diego, CA in April 2022.

The NDSS Symposium brings together innovative and forward-thinking members of the Internet community who research, design, develop, and deploy the technologies that define network and distributed system security. 563 people registered and attended remotely or in-person at least one session or workshop of the NDSS Symposium.  All conference activities are listed on the conference program page: https://www.ndss-symposium.org/ndss-program/ndss-2022. 

This award provided valuable career development and learning opportunities for the supported students. Attending conferences is an important component of graduate school education for our society's future computer security researchers. Students had the opportunity to discuss leading edge research with world-class computer security researchers, and establish networks, connections, and mentoring relationships that will serve them well during their research careers. Student participation is vital to preparing the next generation of technical leaders to address rising threats to the security and resilience of the Internet.

Interested students were invited to apply for the student support through an announcement on the Internet Society’s website as well as announcements on social media and other relevant email lists of educators and researchers in the security field. Women and under-represented groups were actively encouraged to apply.


Last Modified: 05/10/2023
Modified by: Karen O'donoghue
